{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2011}} [[File:Christopher Hitchens crop 2.jpg|200px|thumb|Hitchens, wearing a Kurdish flag pin (just behind his left index finger), speaking at the 2007 [[Amaz!ng Meeting]] at the [[Riviera (hotel and casino)|Riviera Hotel]], [[Las Vegas]] ]]
[[Christopher Hitchens]] (13 April 1949 – 15 December 2011) was a British-American<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BS3i-Mz3I_UC&pg=PT384|title=Hitch 22: A Memoir|publisher=Atlantic Books Ltd|date=20 May 2010|author=Christopher Hitchens|accessdate=7 July 2015|isbn=9781848877535}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/culturenews/8961815/Christopher-Hitchens-a-sober-perception-however-much-he-drank.html|title=Christopher Hitchens: a sober perception, however much he drank|date=17 December 2011|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freerepublic.com/focus/f-news/1612244/posts|title=transcript: Hitchens on the Hugh Hewitt radio program ... on immigration|publisher=|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref> author, [[polemic]]ist, [[debate]]r and journalist who in his youth took part in demonstrations against the Vietnam War, joined organisations such as the [[International Socialists (UK)|International Socialists]] while at university<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Seymour|first1=Richard|title=The late Christopher Hitchens|journal=[[International Socialism (magazine)|International Socialism]]|date=27 March 2012|issue=134|url=http://isj.org.uk/the-late-christopher-hitchens/|accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> and began to identify as a [[socialism|socialist]]. However, after the [[September 11 attacks|11 September attacks]] he no longer regarded himself as a socialist and his political thinking became largely dominated by the issue of defending civilization from [[terrorism|terrorists]] and against the [[totalitarianism|totalitarian]] regimes that protect them. Hitchens nonetheless continued to identify as a [[Marxism|Marxist]], endorsing the [[materialist conception of history]], but believed that [[Karl Marx]] had underestimated the revolutionary nature of capitalism.<ref>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2009/04/the-revenge-of-karl-marx/307317/ |title=The Revenge of Karl Marx |work=The Atlantic |date=1 April 2009 |accessdate=1 June 2009 }}</ref> He sympathized with [[libertarian]] ideals of [[limited government|limited state interference]], but considered libertarianism not to be a viable system. In the [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 U.S. presidential election]], he supported the independent candidate [[Ralph Nader]]. After 9/11, Hitchens advocated the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]]. In the 2004 election, he very slightly favored the incumbent [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] President [[George W. Bush]] or was neutral<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/oct/31/uselections2004.comment2 |title=Christopher Hitchens: Why I'm voting for Bush (but only just) |last=Hitchens |first=Christopher |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=31 October 2004 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> and in 2008 he favored the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] candidate [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2008/10/vote_for_obama.html |title=Vote for Obama |last=Hitchens |first=Christopher |publisher=''Slate'' |date=13 October 2008 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
==Political orientation==
===First principles=== Alexander Linklater has summarized Hitchens' basic intellectual outlook as follows:
{{quote|One of [Hitchens'] old strongholds [was] the 17th-century contest between king and parliament of the [[English civil war]]. For Hitchens, the [[Oliver Cromwell|Cromwellian]] revolt represents not just the foundational struggle for parliamentary rule, but the great rejection of [[Divine Right of Kings|divine right]]. ... But he is no optimistic [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] rationalist. He identifies himself with [[Thomas Paine]]'s disillusion at the [[Reign of Terror|French terror]], and [[Rosa Luxemburg]]'s famous warning to [[Lenin]] about the inexorability of one-man rule. He retains, however, from his [[Marxist]] youth an intellectual absolutism and a disdain for liberal dilemmas and trade-offs – hence a brutal assault on [[Isaiah Berlin]]'s genteel liberalism in a 1998 essay. He is incurious about what religious belief feels like, or what meaning it has for millions of people – even though, unlike his co-anti-religionist [[Richard Dawkins]], Hitchens concedes that religious feeling is ineradicable.<ref>{{cite news |first=Alexander |last=Linklater |url=http://www.prospect-magazine.co.uk/article_details.php?id=10157 |title=Christopher Hitchens |work=[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]] |issue=146 |date=1 May 2008 |accessdate=1 June 2008 }}</ref>}}
===British republicanism=== Hitchens was a vocal supporter of [[Republicanism in the United Kingdom]], advocating the abolition of the Monarchy, and in 1990 published the book-long polemic ''The Monarchy: A Critique of Britain's Favourite Fetish''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hitchens|first1=Christopher|title=Waving? Or drowning?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/jun/12/monarchy.features11|accessdate=9 July 2015|work=The Guardian|date=12 June 2000}}</ref> His 1998 documentary ''Princess Diana: The Mourning After'' accused the British media of playing an essential role in creating a national, unchallengeable, and at times hysterical [[cult of personality]] surrounding the [[death of Diana, Princess of Wales]], whereas previously they had been extremely critical of her and the monarchy after she had separated and divorced from [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], and was having an affair with Egyptian billionaire son [[Dodi Fayed]]. Hitchens claimed the public were behaving irrationally, and that many appeared to not even know why they were mourning. He also scrutinised the level of censorship against criticism of Diana and the monarchy but was accused, in a review by ''[[The Independent]]'', of exaggerating on this point.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/television-its-a-state-of-total-dianarchy-1175026.html |title=Television: It's a state of total Dianarchy |author=Nicholas Barber |work=The Independent |date=30 August 1998 |accessdate=21 April 2016}}</ref>
===Labour Party===
In 1965, Hitchens joined the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] on the very first day he was eligible to vote, but along with the majority of the [[Labour Students|Labour students' organization]] was expelled in 1967, because of what Hitchens called "[[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Harold Wilson]]'s contemptible support for the [[war in Vietnam]]". Since then he stated he had "re-enlisted a few times" back into the Labour Party.<ref name="Tony Blair">{{cite news |first=Christoph |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2005/04/long_live_labor.html |title=Long Live Labor – Why I'm for Tony Blair |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=25 April 2005 |accessdate=1 June 2005 }}</ref><ref name="Labour">{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/features/2009/08/hitchens200908|title=Christopher Hitchens on Britain's Labour Party|work=Vanity Fair}}</ref> In a 2001 interview with ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'', he said, in 1979, that even though he was a member of the Labour Party, that he wasn't going to vote for the Labour Party, nor could he bring himself to "vote conservative." He didn't vote at all in that election. He also stated that by not voting for the Labour Party he was effectively voting for [[Margaret Thatcher]] to win, which he said he had "secretly hoped would happen."<ref name='reason' /> In a 2005 [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|''Vanity Fair'']] article, he endorsed [[Tony Blair]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election]], mainly due to his support for the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]].<ref name="Tony Blair" /> In a 2009 [[Slate (magazine)|''Slate'']] article, he described that in the late 1970s the Labour Party moved to the right and stated that the downfall of the Labour Party was when [[Gordon Brown]] became the Prime Minister.<ref name="Labour" />
===Northern Ireland===
During a debate with [[George Galloway]] in 2005, Hitchens revealed that he was "a lifelong supporter of the [[United Ireland|reunification of Ireland]]," and was critical of Galloway's opposing views on the war, as well as his "insulting" attitude towards the [[U.S. Senate]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.endusmilitarism.org/gallowayhitchensdebate091605.html |title=Galloway vs |publisher=Endusmilitarism.org |date=16 September 2005|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=INy2ysHhgYM|title=George Galloway debates Christopher Hitchens|accessdate=20 November 2007}}</ref> Many times, when discussing "[[the Troubles]]" in Northern Ireland, Hitchens would refer to their location as simply "Ireland", rather than "Northern Ireland", as for example in an article written for ''Slate'' in 2007, discussing the power-sharing and devolved government in Northern Ireland and describing it as "an agreement to divide the spoils of Ireland's six northeastern counties".<ref>{{cite web|last=Applebaum|first=Anne|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2163217/|title=Ian Paisley and Gerry Adams make me want to spew. – Slate Magazine|publisher=Slate.com|date=2 April 2007|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref> During the [[Irish Republican Army|IRA]] bombing campaigns on the British mainland, which began in the nineteen-seventies, Hitchens claimed that he had "kept two sets of books: I didn’t like bombs, I didn’t like the partition of Ireland."<ref name="newyorker.com" />
===Libertarianism and capitalism===
In a 2001 interview with ''Reason'', Hitchens said he had been interested in [[libertarian]] ideas when he was younger, but set aside those interests in the 1960s. He stated that [[capitalism]] had become the more revolutionary economic system, and he welcomed [[globalisation]] as "innovative and [[internationalism (politics)|internationalist]]", but added, "I don't think that the contradictions, as we used to say, of the system, are by any means all resolved." He also stated that he had a renewed interest in the freedom of the individual from the state, but that he still considered libertarianism "ahistorical" both on the world stage and in the work of creating a stable and functional society, adding that libertarians are "more worried about the over-mighty state than the unaccountable corporation" whereas "the present state of affairs ... combines the worst of bureaucracy with the worst of the insurance companies." He also said that libertarians did not have a clear foreign policy stance.<ref name='reason' />
In a 2001 C-SPAN appearance, he told a caller:
{{quote|If you are a libertarian you may find some nourishment in my book ''Letters to a Young Contrarian'' where I say that in the same breath as I-as I mourn the decay of some of my socialist allegiances that deep down I've always been a sympathizer of the libertarian [[anti-statist]] point of view. And one of the things that attracted me to socialism in the beginning was the idea of withering away of the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EMD68Q1vCYk|title=Christopher Hitchens Expresses Affinity w/ Libertarian Principles on CSPAN 2001|work=YouTube}}</ref>}}
=== Objectivism === Hitchens said of [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivism]], “I have always found it quaint, and rather touching, that there is a movement in the US that thinks Americans are not yet selfish enough.”<ref name="masciotra">{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/03/01/libertarianism_is_for_petulant_children_ayn_rand_rand_paul_and_the_movements_sad_rebellion_partner/|title=Libertarianism is for petulant children: Ayn Rand, Rand Paul and the movement’s sad “rebellion”|author=DAVID MASCIOTRA|date=1 March 2015|website=salon.com}}</ref>
===Marxism and socialism===
In a 2001 interview with ''Reason'', Hitchens said he became a [[Marxism|Marxist]] and a [[Trotskyism|Trotskyist]] in his teens, beliefs that further developed during his time at [[Balliol College, Oxford]]. In 1966, he was demonstrating in [[Trafalgar Square]] against the [[Vietnam War]]. In 1967, he joined the [[International Socialist Tendency|International Socialists]] while at Balliol College, Oxford. Under the influence of [[Peter Sedgwick]], who translated the writings of Russian revolutionary and [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] dissident [[Victor Serge]], Hitchens forged an ideological interest in [[Trotskyism|Trotskyist]] and [[Anti-Stalinist left|anti-Stalinist]] socialism. Shortly after he joined "a small but growing post-Trotskyist [[Luxemburgism|Luxemburgist]] sect".<ref name=PBSinterview /> He became a socialist "largely [as] the outcome of a study of history, taking sides ... in the battles over industrialism and war and empire." He was also drawn into the [[Left-wing politics|political left]] by his anger over the [[Vietnam War]], [[nuclear weapon]]s, racism and "[[oligarchy]]", including that of "the unaccountable corporation." He also said in the same interview with ''Reason'' that he could no longer say "I am a socialist". Socialists, he claimed, had ceased to offer a positive alternative to the capitalist system.<ref name='reason'>{{cite news|author=Rhys Southan from the November 2001 issue|url=http://reason.com/archives/2001/11/01/free-radical|title=Free Radical|work=Reason|accessdate=26 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/reviews/hitch22-a-memoir-by-christopher-hitchens-1984845.html|title=Hitch-22: a memoir by Christopher Hitchens|work=The Independent}}</ref>
In 2006, in a town hall meeting in Pennsylvania debating the [[Judaism|Jewish Tradition]] with Martin Amis, Hitchens commented on his political philosophy by stating, "I am no longer a socialist, but I still am a [[Marxist]]".<ref>{{YouTube|K6rRA64f9ug|Martin Amis Christopher Hitchens a conversation about Antisemitism and Saul Bellow Part 3}}</ref> In a June 2010 interview with ''The New York Times'', he stated that "I still think like a Marxist in many ways. I think the [[Historical materialism|materialist conception of history]] is valid. I consider myself a very conservative Marxist".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/06/magazine/06fob-q4-t.html|title=The Contrarian|first=Deborah|last=Solomon|work=The New York Times|date=2 June 2010|accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref> In 2009, in an article for ''The Atlantic'' entitled "The Revenge of Karl Marx", Hitchens frames the [[late-2000s recession]] in terms of [[Marxist economics|Marx's economic analysis]] and notes how much Marx admired the capitalist system that he called for the end of, but says that Marx ultimately failed to grasp how revolutionary capitalist innovation was.<ref>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200904/hitchens-marx |title=The Revenge of Karl Marx |work=The Atlantic |date=1 April 2009 |accessdate=1 May 2009 }}</ref> Hitchens was an admirer of [[Che Guevara]], yet in an essay written in 1997, he distanced himself from Che, and referred to the mythos surrounding him as a "cult".<ref>{{cite web |last=Hitchens |first=Christopher |url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/1997/jul/17/goodbye-to-all-that/ |title=Goodbye to All That |work=[[The New York Review of Books]] |date=17 July 1997 |accessdate=1 June 2005 }}</ref> In 2004 he re-emphasized his positive view of Che, commenting that "[Che's] death meant a lot to me and countless like me at the time. He was a role model, albeit an impossible one for us [[bourgeois]] [[Romanticism|romantics]] insofar as he went and did what revolutionaries were meant to do – fought and died for his beliefs."<ref name=prettyface>{{cite news |first=Sean |last=O'Hagan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/jul/11/features.review |title=Just a Pretty Face? |work=The Guardian |date=11 July 2004 |accessdate=1 August 2005 }}</ref>
He continued to regard [[Leon Trotsky]] and [[Vladimir Lenin]] as great men,<ref>{{cite book|last=Amis|first=Martin|title=Koba the Dread|publisher=Miramax|year=2002|page=25|isbn=978-0-7868-6876-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Matthew |last=Parris |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/history/greatlives/index_series7.shtml |title=Great Lives – Leon Trotsky |publisher=BBC Radio 4 |date=8 August 2006 |accessdate=1 September 2006 }}</ref> and the [[October Revolution]] as a necessary event in the modernisation of Russia.<ref name='reason' /><ref name=PBSinterview>{{cite web |first=Christopher |last=Hithens |url=https://www.pbs.org/heavenonearth/interviews_hitchens.html |title=Heaven on Earth – Interview with Christopher Hitchens |publisher=PBS |date=1 January 2005 |accessdate=1 January 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060612210516/http://www.pbs.org/heavenonearth/interviews_hitchens.html |archivedate=12 June 2006 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> In 2005, Hitchens praised Lenin's creation of "secular Russia" and his attacks on the [[Russian Orthodox Church]], describing the church's power as "absolute warren of backwardness and evil and superstition".<ref name=PBSinterview/>
In ''[[God is not Great]]'', Hitchens called Marxism his "own secular faith" that "has been shaken and discarded, not without pain." He referred to his period of Marxist faith as "when I was a Marxist."<ref>Hitchens, Christopher (May 2007). God is not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything. New York: Twelve Books, ch. 10 </ref>
According to [[Andrew Sullivan]], his last words were "Capitalism, downfall."<ref name="Sullivan">{{cite web |url=http://andrewsullivan.thedailybeast.com/2012/04/hitchs-service.html |title=The Hitch Has Landed |last1=Sullivan |first1=Andrew |date=20 April 2012 |publisher=The Daily Beast |accessdate=13 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423014036/http://andrewsullivan.thedailybeast.com/2012/04/hitchs-service.html |archivedate=23 April 2012 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
===American presidential endorsements===
====President Bill Clinton====
Hitchens became increasingly disenchanted by the presidency of [[Bill Clinton]], accusing him of being a rapist and a liar.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hitchens: Clinton could sell out Blair|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/354470.stm|date=3 June 1999|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=25 May 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=No One Left to Lie to: The Triangulations of William Jefferson Clinton|last=Hitchens|first=Christopher|publisher=Verso Books|year=1999|isbn=978-1-85984-736-7}}</ref> Hitchens also claimed that the [[Operation Infinite Reach|missile attacks]] by Clinton on [[Sudan]] constituted a [[war crime]].<ref>Christopher Hitchens, ''No One Left To Lie To'' (Verso, 2000)</ref>
====2000 United States presidential election====
[[File:DebateCommissionProtest 2000.JPG|thumb|left|Hitchens speaking at a September 2000 [[Third party (United States)|third party]] protest at the headquarters of the [[Commission on Presidential Debates]]]]
Hitchens supported [[Ralph Nader]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 US presidential election]].<ref name=bloggingheads>{{cite web |author1=Alterman, Eric |author2=Hitchens, Christopher |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://bloggingheads.tv/diavlogs/15143 |title=On Whether Christopher Hitchens Was Wrong |publisher=Bloggingheads.tv |date=14 October 2008 |accessdate=1 November 2008 }}</ref> He elaborated on his support for Nader in a discussion with [[Eric Alterman]] on [[Bloggingheads.tv]], indicating that he was disenchanted with the candidacy of both George W. Bush and [[Al Gore]].<ref name=bloggingheads />
==== President George Bush ====
Prior to 11 September 2001, and the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]], Hitchens was critical of President [[George W. Bush]]'s "[[non-interventionism|non-interventionist]]" foreign policy. He also criticised Bush's support of [[intelligent design]]<ref name=autogenerated4>{{cite news |last=Belz |first=Mindy |url=http://www.worldmag.com/articles/11908 |title=According to Hitch |work=World Magazine |date=3 April 2006 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060602004910/http://www.worldmag.com/articles/11908 |archivedate=2 June 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and [[Capital punishment in Texas|capital punishment]].<ref name=AWarToBeProudOf>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/article/7193 |title=A War To Be Proud Of |work=Weekly Standard |date=5 September 2005 |accessdate=1 November 2005 }}</ref> Hitchens defended Bush's post-11 September foreign policy, but he also criticised the actions of US troops in [[Abu Ghraib]] and [[Haditha]], and the US government's use of [[waterboarding]], which, after voluntarily undergoing it, he argued was definitely [[torture]].<ref name=believeme>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/features/2008/08/hitchens200808 |title=Believe Me, It's Torture |work=Vanity Fair |date=1 August 2008 |accessdate=1 September 2008 }}</ref><ref name=vfwaterboardvideo>{{cite web |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/features/video/2008/hitchens_video200808 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809003051/http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/features/video/2008/hitchens_video200808 |title=Video: On the Waterboard|archivedate=9 August 2011|work=Vanity Fair}}</ref>
====2004 United States presidential election====
Hitchens supported [[George W. Bush]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 US presidential election]].<ref name="newyorker.com">{{cite web |last=Parker |first=Ian |title=He Knew He Was Right: How a former socialist became the Iraq war's fiercest defender. |work=[[The New Yorker]] |date=16 October 2006 |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2006/10/16/he-knew-he-was-right-2 |accessdate=3 August 2016}}</ref> He made a brief return to ''The Nation'' just before the election and wrote that he was "slightly" for Bush; shortly afterwards, ''Slate'' polled its staff on their positions on the candidates and mistakenly printed Hitchens's vote as pro-[[John Kerry]]. Hitchens shifted his opinion to "neutral", saying: "It's absurd for liberals to talk as if [[Kristallnacht]] is impending with Bush, and it's unwise and indecent for Republicans to equate Kerry with capitulation. There's no one to whom he can surrender, is there? I think that the nature of the [[jihad]]ist enemy will decide things in the end".<ref>{{cite news |first=Christpher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2004/11/my_endorsement_and_osamas_video.html |title=My Endorsement and Osama's Video: The news in Bin Laden's comments had nothing to do with our election |work=Slate |date=1 November 2004 |accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref>
====2008 United States presidential election====
Hitchens supported [[Barack Obama]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 presidential election]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Tomasky |first=Michael |title=Hitchens for Obama |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=14 October 2008 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/michaeltomasky/2008/oct/14/barackobama-uselections2008-hitchens |accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> In an article for ''Slate'' he stated, "I used to call myself a [[single-issue voter]] on the essential question of defending civilization against its terrorist enemies and their totalitarian protectors, and on that 'issue' I hope I can continue to expose and oppose any ambiguity." He was critical of both main party candidates, Obama and [[John McCain]], but wrote that Obama would be the better choice. Hitchens went on to call McCain "senile", and his choice of running mate [[Sarah Palin]] "absurd", calling Palin a "pathological liar" and a "national disgrace". Hitchens also wrote that "Obama is greatly overrated" and that the Obama-Biden ticket "show[s] some signs of being able and willing to profit from experience".<ref>{{cite news |last=Hitchens |first=Christopher |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2008/10/vote_for_obama.html |title=Vote for Obama |work=Slate |date=13 October 2008 |accessdate=5 November 2009 }}</ref>
===The American Revolution=== After his disenchantment with socialism, Hitchens increasingly emphasized the centrality of the [[American Revolution]] and the [[U.S. Constitution]] to his political philosophy. As early as 2002, Hitchens wrote, "as the third millennium gets under way, and as the [[Russian Revolution|Russian]] and [[Chinese Revolution (1949)|Chinese]] and [[Cuban Revolution|Cuban]] revolutions drop below the horizon, it is possible to argue that the American revolution, with its promise of cosmopolitan democracy, is the only ‘model’ revolution that humanity has left to it".<ref>Hitchens, Christopher (2002), ''[[Why Orwell Matters]]'', [[Basic Books]], pg 105</ref> His enthusiasm for the [[U.S. Bill of Rights]] contrasts with a dim opinion of constitutional politics on the other side of the Atlantic. Hitchens notes, "the utter failure [of the EU] to compose a viable constitution" and the "brevity of the British constitution, perhaps because the motherland of the English-speaking peoples has absent-mindedly failed to evolve one in written form".<ref>Hitchens, Christopher (2007), ''An Anglosphere Future'', [[City Journal (New York)|City Journal]], Reprinted in ''[[Arguably]]'', page 105</ref>
==Foreign policy==
===Bosnian War=== Hitchens cited the [[Bosnian War]] as something that monumentally changed his views on [[military intervention]], noting that he for the first time found himself on the side of [[Neoconservatism|neoconservatives]]. In an interview with [[Johann Hari]] he said:
{{quote|That war in the early 1990s changed a lot for me. I never thought I would see, in Europe, a full-dress reprise of internment camps, the mass murder of civilians, the reinstiutution [sic] of torture and rape as acts of policy. And I didn't expect so many of my comrades to be indifferent – or even take the side of the fascists. It was a time when many people on the left were saying 'Don't intervene, we'll only make things worse' or, 'Don't intervene, it might destabilise the region. And I thought – destabilisation of fascist regimes is a good thing. Why should the left care about the stability of undemocratic regimes? Wasn't it a good thing to destabilise the regime of General Franco? It was a time when the left was mostly taking the conservative, status quo position – leave the Balkans alone, leave Milosevic alone, do nothing. And that kind of conservatism can easily mutate into actual support for the aggressors. Weimar-style conservatism can easily mutate into National Socialism. So you had people like Noam Chomsky's co-author Ed Herman go from saying 'Do nothing in the Balkans', to actually supporting Milosevic, the most reactionary force in the region. That's when I began to first find myself on the same side as the neocons. I was signing petitions in favour of action in Bosnia, and I would look down the list of names and I kept finding, there's Richard Perle. There's Paul Wolfowitz. That seemed interesting to me. These people were saying that we had to act. Before, I had avoided them like the plague, especially because of what they said about General Sharon and about Nicaragua. But nobody could say they were interested in oil in the Balkans, or in strategic needs, and the people who tried to say that – like Chomsky – looked ridiculous. So now I was interested.<ref>{{cite web|author=Johann – 23 September 2004|url=http://www.johannhari.com/2004/09/23/in-enemy-territory-an-interview-with-christopher-hitchens|title=In enemy territory? An interview with Christopher Hitchens. |publisher=Johannhari.com|date=23 September 2004|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref>}}
Hitchens argued that the choice in [[Yugoslavia]] was between a [[Multiethnic society|multi-ethnic]] [[Pluralism (political philosophy)|plural]] democracy led by Muslim president [[Alija Izetbegović]] in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]] and a fascistic, nationalistically inspired [[ethnic cleansing|ethnically-cleansed]] state driven by Serbian leader [[Slobodan Milošević]]. He called Milošević a fascist and a "[[Nazi|national-socialist]]",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VB9uqI62ikA|title=In Defense of WWII: Chapter 5 of 5|publisher=Youtube|accessdate=7 September 2008}}</ref> and condemned his war crimes<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VB9uqI62ikA|title=In Defense of WWII: Chapter 5 of 5|publisher=Youtube|accessdate=7 September 2008}}</ref> in the [[Yugoslav Wars]]. But he also considered the [[Croatia]]n nationalist president [[Franjo Tudjman]] "equally disgusting" for colluding with Milošević on a [[Partition of Bosnia and Herzegovina|partition of Bosnia]] and empowering Croatian war criminals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.frontpagemag.com/readArticle.aspx?ARTID=5221|title=Shed No Tears for Milosevic|work=FrontPage Magazine|accessdate=7 September 2008|date=14 March 2006}}</ref> In ''God Is Not Great'', he wrote about [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Christian Orthodox]] Serbian and Roman Catholic Croatian nationalism- and religion-inspired crimes against the Muslim Bosnians, at the hands of proponents of "[[Greater Serbia]]" and Croatian "revived [[Ustashe]] formations" during this period which are "often forgotten".<ref>Hitchens, Christopher (May 2007). God is not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything. New York: Twelve Books, pp. 21-23.</ref> He was highly critical of Western inaction in protection of the Muslims, partially blaming this on the Clinton administration and specifically [[Hillary Clinton]].
{{quote|In effect, the extremist Catholic and Orthodox forces were colluding in a bloody partition and cleansing of [[Bosnia-Herzegovina]]. They were, and still are, largely spared the public shame of this, because the world's media preferred the simplification of "Croat" and "Serb," and only mentioned religion when discussing "the Muslims." But the triad of terms "Croat," "Serb," and "Muslim" is unequal and misleading, in that it equates two nationalities and one religion. (The same blunder is made in a different way in coverage of Iraq, with the "[[Sunni]]-[[Shia]]-[[Kurd]]" trilateral.)<ref>Hitchens, Christopher ''God is not great:how religion poisons everything'' Hachette Book Group USA, 2007, Page 20-22</ref>}}
===Gulf War=== Hitchens deplored and opposed the 1990–91 [[Gulf War]] in which the US expelled Iraq from Kuwait after a seven-month invasion and occupation of its neighbor undertaken in an effort to absorb it as its [[Kuwait Governorate|19th province]]. He contended that President [[George H. W. Bush]]'s supposedly principled enthusiasm for the "cause" of "liberating" Kuwait was nothing more than ''[[realpolitik]]''. In the continuation of a national policy dating back to [[Henry Kissinger]] and [[Richard Nixon]] in 1972, the latest "cause was yet another move in the policy of keeping a region divided and embittered, and therefore accessible to the franchisers of weaponry and the owners of black gold".<ref>{{cite web |last=Hitchens |first=Christopher |url=http://harpers.org/archive/1991/01/why-we-are-stuck-in-the-sand/ |title=Why We Are Stuck in the Sand: Realpolitik in the Gulf |work=[[Harper's Magazine|Harper's]] |date=1 January 1991 |accessdate=1 February 2004}}</ref>
However, after the war, Hitchens scolded those within the US who had opposed the war by observing that "the peace movement in this country in my opinion acted in a very narrow, isolationist, and almost chauvinistic way. It said that a war was more or less alright with it as long as it could be guaranteed in advance that American casualties could be kept low... I thought that was a dishonourably narrow way of approaching the question. ... When large numbers of Iraqis were turned into soap...and many others, as we've since found out, were bulldozed and buried alive and in other ways done away with and people don't even want to think about the body count ...because they’re afraid of what they might find out."<ref>Hitchens, Christopher, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=euM_17PL8Fc "The Middle East and American Democracy"], Keynote Speech, 45th Annual Conference of the [[Middle East Institute]]; Broadcast on [[CSPAN2]], 4 October 1991. (Comments are about 37 minutes into this Youtube clip.)</ref>
===Israeli−Palestinian conflict=== Hitchens described [[Zionism]] as being based on [[Theodor Herzl|Herzl]]'s "initial [[demagogue|demagogic]] lie (actually two lies) that [[A land without a people for a people without a land|a land without a people needs a people without a land]]." He went further, saying "Zionism is a form of Bourgeoisie Nationalism" when debating the Jewish Tradition with Martin Amis at a Town hall function in Pennsylvania"<ref name=FrontPage>{{cite web|url=http://www.frontpagemag.com/Articles/ReadArticle.asp?ID=11253|title=Frontpage Interview: Christopher Hitchens Part II|publisher=Front Page Magazine|accessdate=9 May 2007}}</ref> Hitchens supported [[Israel]]'s right to exist, but argued that "one must not insult or degrade or humiliate people"<ref name=FrontPage /> and that he "would be opposed to this maltreatment of the Palestinians if it took place on a remote island with no geopolitical implications".
Hitchens described Zionism as "an ethno-nationalist quasi-religious ideology" but argued that Zionism "... nonetheless has founded a sort of democratic state which isn't any worse in its practice than many others with equally dubious origins." He stated that [[Israeli settlement|settlement]] in order to achieve security for Israel is "doomed to fail in the worst possible way", and the cessation of this "appallingly racist and messianic delusion" would "confront the internal clerical and chauvinist forces which want to instate a theocracy for Jews". Hitchens contended that the "solution of withdrawal would not satisfy the jihadists" and wondered "What did they imagine would be the response of the followers of the [[Muhammad|Prophet]] [Muhammad]?" Hitchens bemoaned the transference of Arab secularism into [[religious terrorism]] as a means of democratisation: "the most depressing and wretched spectacle of the past decade, for all those who care about democracy and secularism, has been the degeneration of Palestinian Arab nationalism into the theocratic and thanatocratic hell of [[Hamas]] and [[Islamic Jihad Movement in Palestine|Islamic Jihad]]".<ref name="Slate60"/> He maintained that the Israel-Palestine conflict is a "trivial squabble" that has become "so dangerous to all of us" because of "the faith-based element."<ref name="FrontPage"/>
On 14 November 2004, Hitchens noted: {{quote|Edward Said asked many times, in public and private, where the [[Nelson Mandela|Mandela]] of Palestine could be. In rather bold contrast to this decent imagination, [[Yasser Arafat|Arafat]] managed to be both a killer and a compromiser (Mandela was neither), both a [[Swiss bank account]] artist and a populist ranter (Mandela was neither), both an Islamic "martyrdom" blow-hard and a servile opportunist, and a man who managed to establish a dictatorship over his own people before they even had a state (here one simply refuses to mention Mandela in the same breath).<ref name=Arafat>{{cite web|url=http://slate.com/id/2109860/|title=Arafat's Squalid End|publisher=Slate|accessdate=9 May 2007}}</ref>}}
Hitchens had previously collaborated on this issue with [[Edward Said]], publishing the 1988 book ''[[Blaming the Victims|Blaming the Victims: Spurious Scholarship and the Palestinian Question]]''.<ref>{{cite web |last=Campbell |first=John C. |title=Blaming The Victims: Spurious Scholarship And The Palestinian Question |work=[[Foreign Affairs]] |date=Spring 1988 |url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/reviews/capsule-review/1988-03-01/blaming-victims-spurious-scholarship-and-palestinian-question |accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref>
Hitchens had said of himself, "I am an [[anti-Zionism|Anti-Zionist]]. I'm one of those people of Jewish descent who believes that [[Zionism]] would be a mistake even if there were no [[Palestinian people|Palestinians]]."<ref name="HölblingRieser-Wohlfarter2004">{{cite book|first1=Walter|last1= Hölbling|first2=Klaus|last2= Rieser-Wohlfarter|title=What is American?: new identities in U.S. culture| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Tn7LqhWI7IC&pg=PA351|accessdate=6 April 2011|year=2004|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|isbn=978-3-8258-7734-7|pages=351–}}</ref>
A review of his autobiography ''Hitch-22'' in ''[[The Jewish Daily Forward]]'' refers to Hitchens "at the time [that he had learned that his grandparents were Jews, he had been] a prominent anti-Zionist" and says that he viewed Zionism "as an injustice against the Palestinians".<ref name="Forward">{{cite journal |url=http://www.forward.com/articles/128323/ |title=Born Grumpy, with a Talent for It: Christopher Hitchens's Memoir is Too Happy by Far |last=Goldstein|first=Evan R.|journal=The Jewish Daily Forward|date=June 2010}}</ref> Others have commented on his anti-Zionism as well.<ref name="Rodden2006">{{cite book|first=John|last= Rodden |title=Every intellectual's big brother: George Orwell's literary siblings |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UlnwITCGcw8C&pg=PA95|accessdate=6 April 2011 |year=2006|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-71308-6|pages=95–}}</ref> At other times for example speaking at 2nd annual Memorial for [[Daniel Pearl]], and in print in an article for ''[[The Atlantic]]'' he had made comments against the terrorism against Jews in the Middle East. Hitchens stated "But the Jews of the Arab lands were expelled again in revenge for the defeat of Palestinian nationalistic aspirations, in 1947–48, and now the absolute most evil and discredited fabrication of Jew-baiting Christian Europe – The Protocols of the Elders of Zion – is eagerly promulgated in the Hamas charter and on the group's Web site and recycled through a whole nexus of outlets that includes schools as well as state-run television stations".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2010/09/chosen/308173/|title=Chosen|author=Christopher Hitchens|date=11 August 2010|work=The Atlantic}}</ref>
In ''Slate'' magazine, Hitchens pondered the notion that, instead of curing [[antisemitism]] through the creation of a Jewish state, "Zionism has only replaced and repositioned"<ref name="Slate60">{{cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2191193/|title=Slate: Can Israel Survive for Another 60 Years?|work=Slate.com|accessdate=8 July 2011}}</ref> it, saying: "there are three groups of 6 million Jews. The first 6 million live in what the Zionist movement used to call Palestine. The second 6 million live in the United States. The third 6 million are distributed mainly among Russia, France, Britain, and Argentina. Only the first group lives daily in range of missiles that can be (and are) launched by people who hate Jews." Hitchens argued that instead of supporting Zionism, Jews should help "secularise and reform their own societies", believing that unless one is religious, "what the hell are you doing in the greater Jerusalem area in the first place?" Indeed, Hitchens claimed that the only justification for Zionism given by Jews is a religious one.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kerstein|first=Benjamin|title=Christopher Hitchens's Jewish Problem|url=http://www.jewishideasdaily.com/content/module/2010/12/13/main-feature/1/christopher-hitchenss-jewish-problem|publisher=[[Jewish Ideas Daily]]|accessdate=9 May 2012}}</ref>
===Kurdistan===
Hitchens was a longtime observer of the cruelty of Saddam Hussein and publicly called for his removal, albeit only beginning in 1998.<ref name="newyorker.com"/> This led him to support the establishment of a self-governing state for the [[Kurds]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b_2_c7GW-ss|title=Christopher Hitchens talks about the Kurdish people|publisher=Youtube|accessdate=6 April 2013}}</ref> with political autonomy, if not full independence.
{{quote|During the many years I spent on the Left, the cause of self-determination for [[Kurdistan]] was high on the list of principles and priorities – there are many more Kurds than there are Palestinians and they have been staunch fighters for democracy in the region.<ref>[[Simon Cottee]], Thomas Cushman, Christopher Hitchens (2008), [https://books.google.com/books?id=lctUC8fiaNsC ''Christopher Hitchens and His Critics: Terror, Iraq, and the Left''], page unknown (2nd of Chapter 21 ''I Wanted It to Rain on Their Parade'').</ref>}}
He also consistently wore a [[lapel pin]] with the [[flag of Kurdistan]] on it, to show his solidarity with the Kurds.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
===War on Terror===
====September 11 attacks====
In the months following the 9/11 attacks, Hitchens and [[Noam Chomsky]] debated the nature of [[Islamism|radical Islam]] and the proper response to it in a highly charged exchange of letters in ''The Nation'', including discussion of whether any comparison could be legitimately made between the 9/11 attacks and the [[Operation Infinite Reach|1998 Al Shifa bombing]] by the US.<ref>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/sin-left-islamic-fascism |title=Of Sin, the Left & Islamic Fascism |work=The Nation |date=4 September 2001 |accessdate=1 June 2005 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/blaming-bin-laden-first |title=Blaming bin Laden First |work=The Nation |date=4 October 2001 |accessdate=1 June 2005 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Noam |last=Chomsky |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/reply-hitchens |title=Reply to Hitchens |work=thenation.com |date=1 October 2001 |accessdate=1 June 2005 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Christoph |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/rejoinder-noam-chomsky|title=A Rejoinder to Noam Chomsky|work=thenation.com |date=4 October 2001 |accessdate=1 June 2005 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Noam |last=Chomsky |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/reply-hitchenss-rejoinder |title=Reply to Hitchens's Rejoinder |work=The Nation |date=4 October 2001 }}</ref> Approximately a year after the 9/11 attacks and his exchanges with Chomsky, Hitchens left ''The Nation'', claiming that its editors, readers and contributors considered [[John Ashcroft]] a bigger threat than [[Osama bin Laden]],<ref>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/taking-sides |title=Taking Sides |work=The Nation |date=26 September 2002 |accessdate=1 June 2005 }}</ref> and were making excuses on behalf of Islamist terrorism; in the following months he wrote articles increasingly at odds with his former colleagues. Hitchens was also severely criticized by [[Norman Finkelstein]], an American political scientist and Hitchens's former friend. Citing Hitchens's support for the Iraq and Afghanistan Wars, as well as Hitchens's critique of [[Mel Gibson]]'s ''[[Passion of the Christ]]'', Finkelstein called Hitchens a "model apostate," a "dirt bag," and a "showboat run amuck" who is "dying for the camera."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mgB20YmqN6A|title=Norman Finkelstein Attacks The Holocaust Industry, Etc.|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref>
====War in Afghanistan====
Hitchens strongly supported US military actions in [[Afghanistan]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Cockburn |first=Patrick |authorlink=Patrick Cockburn |title=Patrick Cockburn: Christopher Hitchens made a cogent case for war – but he was still wrong |work=[[The Independent]] |date=28 April 2012 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/patrick-cockburn-christopher-hitchens-made-a-cogent-case-for-war-but-he-was-still-wrong-7687385.html |accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> particularly in his "Fighting Words" columns in ''[[Slate magazine|Slate]]''.
====Iraq War==== Hitchens' employment of the term "Islamofascist" and his support for the [[Iraq War]] caused his critics to label him a "[[neoconservative]]". Hitchens, however, refused to embrace this designation,<ref name=Debate>{{cite web|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2004/10/12/tariq_ali_v_christopher_hitchens_a|title=Tariq Ali v. Christopher Hitchens|publisher=Democracy Now|accessdate=9 May 2007}}</ref><ref name=SituationRoom>{{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0611/01/sitroom.03.html|title=The Situation Room, Nov. 1, 2006|publisher=CNN|accessdate=4 June 2009}}</ref> insisting, "I'm not any kind of conservative".<ref name=HitchGallowayGuardian>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2005/sep/18/otherparties.iraq|title=The big showdown: Andrew Anthony on Hitchens v Galloway|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=4 June 2009|date=18 September 2005}}</ref> In 2004, Hitchens stated that neoconservative support for US intervention in [[Iraq War|Iraq]] convinced him that he was "on the same side as the neo-conservatives" when it came to contemporary [[foreign policy]] issues, and characterized himself as an unqualified "supporter of Paul Wolfowitz."<ref name="InEnemyTerritory">{{cite web |first=Johann |last=Hari |url=http://johannhari.com/2004/09/23/in-enemy-territory-an-interview-with-christopher-hitchens/ |title=In Enemy Territory: An Interview with Christopher Hitchens |work=[[The Independent]] |date=23 September 2004 |accessdate=1 June 2005 }}</ref> He was also known to refer to his association with "temporary neocon allies".<ref name="EndOfFukuyama">{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2137134 |title=The End of Fukuyama |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=1 March 2006 |accessdate=1 June 2007 }}</ref> In this period he opined that "the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]] [...] has redefined the lazy term 'conservative' to mean someone who is impatient with the status quo."<ref name=ahmad>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2004/05/ahmad_and_me.html |title=Ahmad and Me |work=Slate |date=27 May 2004 |accessdate=1 January 2005}}</ref>
In the years after the ''[[fatwa]]'' [[The Satanic Verses controversy#Fatwā by Ayatollah Khomeini|issued against Salman Rushdie]] in response to his novel ''[[The Satanic Verses]]'', Hitchens became increasingly critical of what he called "excuse making" on the left. At the same time, he was attracted to the foreign policy ideas of some on the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]-right that promoted pro-liberalism intervention, especially the [[neoconservative]] group that included [[Paul Wolfowitz]].<ref name=bleeding>{{cite news |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2005/03/that_bleeding_heart_wolfowitz.html |title=That Bleeding Heart Wolfowitz |work=Slate |date=22 March 2005 |accessdate=1 June 2005}}</ref> Around this time, he befriended the [[Iraqi people|Iraqi]] dissident and businessman [[Ahmed Chalabi]].<ref name=ahmad />
Christopher Hitchens argued the case for the Iraq War in a 2003 collection of essays entitled ''[[A Long Short War: The Postponed Liberation of Iraq]]'', and participated in public debates on the topic with [[George Galloway]],<ref name=autogenerated5>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KZnUIeKOIgc|title=George Galloway vs Christopher Hitchens (1 of 12)|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=26 April 2011}}</ref> [[Scott Ritter]],<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HU45ioYvx4k|title=Christopher Hitchens versus Ritter – Iraq War debate part 1|publisher=YouTube|date=30 April 2009|accessdate=26 April 2011}}</ref> and his brother [[Peter Hitchens]].<ref name="FPW2008">{{cite web|url=http://hauensteincenter.org/hitchens-vs-hitchens-faith-politics-war|title=Hitchens v. Hitchens: Faith, Politics & War|date=3 April 2008|accessdate=12 March 2015|publisher=Grand Valley State University}}</ref> In its obituary of Hitchens, ''The Economist'' wrote that, "on the most consequential political issue of the last decade of his life, the bullshit got him."<ref>[https://www.economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2011/12/christopher-hitchens "Christopher Hitchens: The struggle against bullshit" ''The Economist'', 16 December 2011]</ref>
====Human Rights Violations at Abu Ghraib and Haditha====
Hitchens criticised human rights abuses by US forces in Iraq but argued that conditions had improved considerably compared either to Saddam Hussein's previous regime or to previous US military actions in Vietnam.
In 2005, Hitchens criticised the abuse of prisoners in Abu Ghraib but argued that overall "prison conditions at [[Abu Ghraib]] have improved markedly and dramatically since the arrival of Coalition troops in Baghdad",<ref name=AWarToBeProudOf /> arguing that "before March 2003, Abu Ghraib was an [[abattoir]], a [[torture chamber]], and a [[concentration camp]]."<ref name=AWarToBeProudOf />
In a 5 June 2006 article on the alleged killings of Iraqi civilians by U.S. Marines in [[Haditha]], Hitchens argued that whether or not a massacre had taken place, comparisons with the [[My Lai]] massacre in Vietnam were "so much propaganda and hot air" that ignored substantial changes in the [[rules of engagement]] and US Army procedures and training designed to prevent and discourage such an event. He argued that lesson had been learned such that "as a consequence, a training film about My Lai – "if anything like this happens, you have really, truly screwed up" – has been in use for U. S. soldiers for some time".<ref>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2143011/ |title=The Hell of War |work=Slate |date=5 June 2006 |accessdate=1 February 2007 }}</ref>
====Pre-war American and British Intelligence==== In a variety of articles and interviews, Hitchens asserted that British intelligence was correct in [[Niger uranium forgeries|claiming]] that Saddam had attempted to buy [[uranium]] from [[Niger]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Rybczynski|first=Witold|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2139609/?nav/fo/|title=Wowie Zahawie|publisher=Slate|date=10 April 2006|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref> and that US envoy [[Joseph C. Wilson|Joseph Wilson]] had been dishonest in his public denials of it.<ref>{{cite web|last=Landsburg|first=Steven E.|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2140058/|title=Clueless Joe Wilson|publisher=Slate|date=17 April 2006|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref> He also pointed to discovered munitions in Iraq that violated [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 686|U. N. Security Council Resolutions 686]] and [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 687|687]], the cease-fire agreements ending the [[Invasion of Kuwait|1991 Iraq-Kuwait conflict]].
On 19 March 2007, Hitchens asked himself whether Western intelligence sources should have known that Iraq had "no stockpiles of [[weapons of mass destruction]]." In his response, Hitchens stated that:
{{quote|The entire record of [[United Nations Special Commission|UNSCOM]] until that date had shown a determination on the part of the Iraqi dictatorship to build dummy facilities to deceive inspectors, to refuse to allow scientists to be interviewed without coercion, to conceal [[chemical weapons|chemical]] and [[biological weapons|biological]] deposits, and to search the [[black market]] for material that would breach the sanctions. The defection of Saddam Hussein's sons-in-law, the Kamel brothers, had shown that this policy was even more systematic than had even been suspected. Moreover, Iraq did not account for – has in fact never accounted for – a number of the items that it admitted under pressure to possessing after the Kamel defection. We still do not know what happened to this weaponry. This is partly why all Western intelligence agencies, including French and German ones quite uninfluenced by Ahmad Chalabi, believed that Iraq had actual or latent programs for the production of WMD. Would it have been preferable to accept Saddam Hussein's word for it and to allow him the chance to re-equip once more once the sanctions had further decayed?<ref name=deadurl>{{cite news|last1=Hitchens|first1=Christopher|title=So, Mr. Hitchens, weren't you wrong about Iraq?|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2162157/pagenum/all/#page_start|accessdate=7 July 2015|work=Slate|date=19 March 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812013912/http://www.slate.com/id/2162157/pagenum/all/#page_start|archivedate=12 August 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref>}}
====Saddam Hussein==== In July 2007, the ''[[New Statesman]]'' printed selected portions of a 1976 piece by Hitchens which they claimed "took a more admiring view of the Iraqi dictator" than his later strong support for ousting [[Saddam Hussein]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200707050056 |title=Iraq Flexes Arab Muscle |work=[[New Statesman]] |date=5 July 2007 |accessdate=1 August 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070711172014/http://www.newstatesman.com/200707050056 |archivedate=11 July 2007 |deadurl=yes }} (originally published 1976)</ref> In this Hitchens pointed to Iraq's military strength, oil reserves and young leadership to argue that [[Iraq]] was "a force to be reckoned with" and described Saddam Hussein as a leader "who has sprung from being an underground revolutionary gunman to perhaps the first visionary [[Arab]] statesman since [[Nasser]]." He also argued:
{{quote| Iraq, which has this dynamic combination and much else besides, has not until recently been very much regarded as a power. But with the new discussions in [[OPEC]], the ending of the Kurdistan war and the new round of fighting in [[Lebanon]], its political voice is being heard more and more. The [[Baghdad]] regime is the first oil-producing government to opt for 100-per-cent [[nationalisation]], a process completed with the acquisition of foreign assets in [[Basrah]] last December. It was the first to call for the use of oil as a political weapon against Israel and her backers. It gives strong economic and political support to the 'Rejection Front' Palestinians who oppose Arafat's conciliation and are currently trying to outface the Syrians in [[Beirut]].}}
He argued that the means through which the [[Baathist]] regime rose to power were similar to that of [[Iran]]: having crushed any political dissent and notions of an independent [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] state. He stated that the Ba'ath party "point to efforts made by the party press to stimulate criticism of [[Islamic Revolution|revolutionary]] shortcomings" but that these "fall rather short of permitting any organised opposition". He claimed that Iraq defended this by claiming "that the country is surrounded by enemies and attacked by imperialist intrigue" but that this had led to the repression of Kurdish nationalists.
====Waterboarding==== Hitchens was asked by ''[[Vanity Fair magazine|Vanity Fair]]'' to experience [[waterboarding]] for himself at a [[U.S. Army]] training facility. In May 2008, Hitchens voluntarily underwent the procedure. Hitchens stopped the procedure after 11 seconds and subsequently endorsed the view that it was "[[torture]]." He concluded, "If waterboarding does not constitute torture, then there is no such thing as torture."<ref>{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/features/2008/08/hitchens200808 |title=Believe Me, It’s Torture |work=Vanity Fair |date=1 August 2008 |accessdate=1 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Christopher |last=Hitchens |url=http://video.vanityfair.com/watch/watch-christopher-hitchens-get-waterboarded |title=Watch Christopher Hitchens Get Waterboarded |work=Vanity Fair |date=2 July 2008 |accessdate=1 March 2012 }}</ref>
===Lebanon=== Hitchens described Lebanon as "the most plural society in the region" and criticized the Syrian regime for continuing to manipulate the country by proxies and by surrogates notably [[Hezbollah]] and the [[Syrian National Socialist Party|SSNP]]. <ref>https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2009/05/christopher-hitchens200905</ref>
====Hezbollah==== In an article written on ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', Hitchens stated:
{{quote|"In Greek legend there was a fighter named Antaeus who drew strength from the earth even when he was flung down. It took Hercules to work out his vulnerability as a wrestler. Hezbollah loves death, thrives on defeat and disaster, and is rapidly moving from being a [[state within a state]] to becoming the master of what was once the most cosmopolitan and democratic country in the Middle East. Meanwhile, a former superpower – no Hercules – is permitting itself to be made a hostage and laughing-stock by a squalid factional fight within the Israeli right wing involving the time and scale of petty land theft by zealots and fanatics. Only a few years from now, this, too, will seem hard to believe, as well as shameful and unpardonable." <ref>http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2010/10/hezbollahs_progress.html</ref> }}
==Domestic policy==
===Civil liberties===
====Abortion==== [[File:Hell's Angel – Mother Teresa of Calcutta.png|thumb|Titlecard of [[Hell's Angel (documentary)|Hell's Angel]] – Mother Teresa of Calcutta (1994), a documentary by Christopher Hitchens]] Hitchens stated, "[an] unborn child seems to me to be a real concept. It's not a growth or an appendix. You can't say the rights question doesn't come up. I don't think a woman should be forced to choose, or even can be", and, "as a materialist, I think it has been demonstrated that an embryo is a separate body and entity".<ref>God Is Not Great : Is Religion Child Abuse : Page 220 </ref> Showing a desire to recognise the unborn as a life, he also affirmed a need for the right to abortion, stating, "the second-best fallback solution, which may sometimes be desirable for other reasons, is termination of pregnancy... all thinking people recognise a painful conflict of rights and interest in this question" <ref>God Is Not Great : Is Religion Child Abuse : Page 222 </ref>
Hitchens opposed the overturning of [[Roe v. Wade]] and instead hoped for science to develop new solutions to unwanted pregnancies "that will make abortion more like a contraceptive procedure than a surgical one." He strongly criticized the encouragement of [[sexual abstinence]] within the pro-life movement of the [[Christian right]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Miller|first1=Lisa|title=No God – And No Abortions|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/171240|website=newsweek.com|accessdate=7 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203095145/http://www.newsweek.com/id/171240|archivedate=3 December 2008|date=29 November 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> and the equating of contraceptives to abortion, as expressed by [[Mother Teresa]] and representatives of the Roman Catholic Church.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvguide.lastown.com/bbc/preview/newsnight/paxman-meets-hitchens-a-newsnight-special.html |title=Preview Subtitles for Newsnight: Paxman Meets Hitchens: A Newsnight Special |work=TV Guide & Subtitles |accessdate=1 July 2014 }}</ref>
====Capital punishment====
Hitchens was a lifelong opponent of [[capital punishment]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Hitchens |first=Christopher |title=Why we should put an end to the death penalty |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2 January 2005 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/jan/02/books/bk-hitchens2 |accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref> In a 2001 interview with ''Reason'', Hitchens recalled that this was the very first issue on which he ever decided to take a stand in his youth. The reason for his opposition to capital punishment was that it gave too much power to the government.<ref name='reason' /> He later publicly opposed use of the [[Execution of Saddam Hussein|death penalty for Saddam Hussein]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Anthony |first=Andrew |title=Christopher Hitchens: 'You have to choose your future regrets' |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=13 November 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/nov/14/christopher-hitchens-cancer-interview |accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref> an issue he discussed at length in his November 2006 essay "Don't Hang Saddam" for ''Slate''.<ref>{{cite web |last=Hitchens |first=Christopher |title=Don't Hang Saddam: Why the dictator shouldn't get the death penalty. |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=6 November 2006 |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2006/11/dont_hang_saddam.html |accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref>
====Drug policy==== Hitchens has called for the abolition of the "[[War on Drugs]]," which he described as an "authoritarian war" during a debate with [[William F. Buckley]].<ref>{{cite web|title=YOU SAID YOU WANTED A REVOLUTION: 1968 and the Counter-Counterculture|url=http://www.hoover.org/multimedia/uk/3420306.html|website=hoover.org|publisher=Hoover Institution|accessdate=7 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100402175253/http://www.hoover.org/multimedia/uk/3420306.html|archivedate=2 April 2010|date=29 July 1998|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Hitchens favored the legalization of [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] for both recreational and [[Medical cannabis|medicinal purposes]], and said, "Marijuana is a medicine. I have heard and read convincing arguments and had convincing testimony from real people who say that marijuana is a very useful medicine for the treatment of [[chemotherapy]]-induced nausea and for [[glaucoma]]. To keep that out of the reach of the sick, it seems to me, is sadistic".<ref name=prettyface /><ref>Page 571 of the book titled "atheism" by By George H. Smith. [https://books.google.com/books?id=hf7TCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA571 Page 571]</ref>
====Genital integrity==== Hitchens was a notable [[genital integrity]] activist, strongly criticizing the tradition of both [[male circumcision]] and [[female genital mutilation]]. In accordance with his [[antitheism]], Hitchens described the tolerance of ''[[metzitzah b'peh]]'' (a Jewish tradition of sucking blood from the penis after the removal of the male [[foreskin]]) as "another disgusting religious practice".<ref name="slate. com">{{cite web|last=Hitchens|first=Christopher|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2125225/|title=Another disgusting religious practice|work=Slate Magazine|date=29 August 2005|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref>
====Gun rights====
Hitchens philosophically supported [[right to keep and bear arms|gun rights]] and was generally opposed to [[gun control]]. On the subject of the second amendment, Hitchens argued that as both an outright ban on guns and relying on a citizen militia for the national defence were equally as idealistic and utopian, and that as [[gun control]] created a duopoly of force between the state and criminals, it would be more desirable to encourage training among average citizens so they might develop a better relationship with firearms.<ref>{{cite web |last=Hitchens |first=Christopher |url=http://www.hoboes.com/pub/Firearms/Essays/Myth%20of%20Gun%20Control/ |title=The Myth of Gun Control |work=The Nation |date=24 January 1994 |accessdate=1 June 2005 }}</ref> Although Hitchens repeatedly stated a broad support for the [[Right to keep and bear arms in the United States|right to keep and bear arms]], he was not an enthusiastic advocate and he rarely publicly discussed his views.<ref>{{Citation|last=Julian Brown|title=Hitchens on Gun control opponents|date=2015-12-13|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q5grweB5-Yk|accessdate=2016-05-25}}</ref>
====LGBT rights====
Hitchens was a supporter of LGBT rights. He opposed [[sodomy laws]] and supported same-sex marriage. He argued that the legalization of same-sex marriage was the "socialization of homosexuality" and "demonstrates the spread of conservatism" among the gay community.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/SB107827627378044934|title=The Married State|author=Christopher Hitchens|date=3 March 2004|work=WSJ}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/richardminiter/2011/12/16/christopher-hitchens-as-i-knew-him/ |title=Christopher Hitchens, As I Knew Him|author=Richard Miniter |date=16 December 2011 |accessdate=5 January 2012 |work=Forbes}}</ref>
====NSA warrantless surveillance====
In January 2006, Hitchens joined with four other individuals and four organisations, including the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] and [[Greenpeace]], as plaintiffs in a lawsuit, ''[[ACLU v. NSA]]'', challenging Bush's [[NSA warrantless surveillance controversy|warrantless domestic spying program]]; the lawsuit was filed by the ACLU.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lichtblau |first=Eric |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/17/politics/17nsa.html |title=Two Groups Planning to Sue Over Federal Eavesdropping |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=17 January 2006 |accessdate=5 November 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/safefree/nsaspying/23485res20060116.html|title=Statement – Christopher Hitchens, NSA Lawsuit Client|publisher=Aclu.org|date=16 January 2006|accessdate=26 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.truthinjustice.org/govdeath.htm|title=Gov. Death|author=Hitchens, Christopher|accessdate=10 May 2009|date=7 August 1999|publisher=[[Salon.com]]}}</ref>
====Voting rights====
In March 2005, Hitchens supported further investigation into [[2004 U.S. election voting controversies, Ohio|voting irregularities in Ohio]] during the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 presidential election]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailykos.com/stories/2005/2/8/91132/-|title=Christopher Hitchens thinks the Ohio vote was stolen|publisher=dailykos.com|accessdate=18 December 2017}}</ref>
==Religion==
At the [[New York Public Library]] in May 2007, Hitchens debated [[Al Sharpton]] on the issue of [[theism]] and [[Antitheism|anti-theism]], giving rise to a memorable exchange about [[Mormonism]] in particular.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0WXSGmW8LHY|title=Christopher Hitchens vs Al Sharpton - Is god great? [2007]|publisher=Google |date=7 May 2007|accessdate=11 July 2015}}</ref>
In ''[[God is Not Great]]'', Hitchens contended that,
{{quote|above all, we are in need of a renewed Enlightenment, which will base itself on the proposition that the proper study of mankind is man and woman [referencing [[Alexander Pope]]]. This Enlightenment will not need to depend, like its predecessors, on the heroic breakthroughs of a few gifted and exceptionally courageous people. It is within the compass of the average person. The study of literature and poetry, both for its own sake and for the eternal ethical questions with which it deals, can now easily depose the scrutiny of sacred texts that have been found to be corrupt and confected. The pursuit of unfettered scientific inquiry, and the availability of new findings to masses of people by electronic means, will revolutionize our concepts of research and development. Very importantly, the divorce between the sexual life and fear, and the sexual life and disease, and the sexual life and tyranny, can now at last be attempted, on the sole condition that we banish all religions from the discourse. And all this and more is, for the first time in our history, within the reach if not the grasp of everyone.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hitchens|first=Christopher|title=God is not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything|publisher=Twelve Books|date=May 2007|location=New York|page=283}}</ref>}}
Hitchens was accused of "anti-Catholic bigotry" by others, including Brent Bozell and [[UCLA]] Law Professor [[Stephen Bainbridge]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hood|first1=John|title=Hollowed Be Thy Name|url=http://www.miamisunpost.com/0517bound.htm|accessdate=7 July 2015|work=The SunPost|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070521175846/http://www.miamisunpost.com/0517bound.htm|archivedate=21 May 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> When [[Joe Scarborough]] on 12 March 2004 asked Hitchens whether he was "consumed with hatred for conservative Catholics", Hitchens responded that he was not and that he just thinks that "all religious belief is sinister and infantile".<ref>{{cite web |last=Staff |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/4515474/ |title=Scarborough County Transcripts |publisher=MSNBC |date=12 March 2004 |accessdate=1 May 2014 }}</ref>
In 2005, Hitchens praised [[Vladimir Lenin|Lenin]]'s creation of "secular [[Russia]]" and his destruction of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]], describing it as "an absolute warren of backwardness and evil and superstition."<ref name=PBSinterview /> In an interview with ''[[Radar (magazine)|Radar]]'' in 2007, Hitchens said that if the [[Christian right]]'s agenda were implemented in the United States "It wouldn't last very long and would, I hope, lead to civil war, which they will lose, but for which it would be a great pleasure to take part."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.holidaydmitri.com/hitch.html|title=Godless Provocateur Christopher Hitchens Pledges Allegiance to America|publisher=Holidaydmitri.com|date=1 May 2007|accessdate=18 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224095234/http://www.holidaydmitri.com/hitch.html|archivedate=24 February 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 4 April 2009, Hitchens debated Christian philosopher [[William Lane Craig]] at [[Biola University]] on the topic "Does God Exist?" before both a live and closed circuit audience of over 15,000.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.whittierdailynews.com/news/ci_12079851|title=Craig, Hitchens ask 'Does God Exist?' |publisher=[[Whittier Daily News]]|date=5 April 2009|accessdate=24 April 2009}}</ref>
===Islamism===
Hitchens was deeply shocked by the 14 February 1989 ''[[fatwa]]'' against his longtime friend [[Salman Rushdie]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Applebaum|first=Anne|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2135499/|title=Cartoon Debate|publisher=Slate.com|date=4 February 2006|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref> He became increasingly critical of what he called "[[theocracy|theocratic]] fascism" or "fascism with an Islamic face": radical [[Islamists]] who supported the ''fatwa'' against Rushdie and sought the recreation of the medieval [[caliphate]].{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
Hitchens is often credited with coining the term "[[Islamofascism]]", but Hitchens himself denied it, attributing its coinage to [[Malise Ruthven]].<ref name=Neiesbw>{{cite news|last1=Hitchens|first1=Christopher|authorlink1=Christopher Hitchens|title=Defending Islamofascism|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2007/10/defending_islamofascism.html|accessdate=8 January 2016|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=22 October 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=William |last=Safire |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/01/opinion/01iht-edsafire.2988871.html |title=Islamofascism Anyone? |work=The New York Times |date=1 October 2006 |accessdate=25 November 2006 }}</ref> Hitchens did use the term ''Islamic fascism'' for an article he wrote for ''[[The Nation]]'', shortly after the [[September 11 attacks]], but this phrase also had an earlier history. For example, it was used in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' on 13 January 1979; it also appears to have been used by secularists in [[Turkey]] and [[Afghanistan]] to describe their opponents.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
In February 2006, Hitchens helped organize a pro-[[Denmark]] rally outside the Danish Embassy in Washington, DC, in response to the [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy|''Jyllands-Posten'' Muhammad cartoons controversy]].<ref>{{cite web|author=lexi.net|url=http://www.fcpp.org/main/publication_detail.php?PubID=1377|title=Fronter Centre for Foreign Policy interview|publisher=Fcpp.org|date=2 June 2006|accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref>
===Mormonism===
Hitchens was extremely critical of the doctrinal claims of [[Mormonism]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/features/2007/god_is_not_great/mormonism_a_racket_becomes_a_religion.html|title=God Is Not Great|date=27 April 2007|work=Slate Magazine|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref> and opposed the candidacy of [[Mitt Romney]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2011/10/is_mormonism_a_cult_who_cares_it_s_their_weird_and_sinister_beli.html|title=Romney's Mormon Problem|date=17 October 2011|work=Slate Magazine|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox person | name = Quentin Crewe | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Quentin Hugh Dodds | birth_date = {{Birth date|1926|11|14|df=y}} | birth_place = [[London]], England | death_date = {{Death date and age|1998|11|14|1926|11|14|df=y}} | death_place = [[Chipping Norton]], [[Oxfordshire]], England | nationality =British | other_names = | occupation = Author, journalist, adventurer | known_for = }} '''Quentin Hugh Crewe''' (14 November 1926 – 14 November 1998) was an English journalist, author, restaurateur and adventurer. He was diagnosed with [[muscular dystrophy]] at age 6 and it was predicted he would be dead by 16 years old. He was not told this and lived to 72. He wrote regularly for the [[London Evening Standard|''Evening Standard'']], [[Queen (magazine)|''Queen'']] magazine, the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' and ''[[Sunday Mirror]],'' among others.<ref name=nyt>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/01/world/quentin-crewe-72-bon-vivant-who-was-unfazed-by-disability.html|title=Quentin Crewe, 72, Bon Vivant Who Was Unfazed by Disability|last=Thomas|first=Robert McG.|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1998-12-01|accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-quentin-crewe-1185256.html|title=Obituary: Quentin Crewe|last=De Moubray|first=Jocelyn|work=[[The Independent]]|date=1998-11-16|accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref> Crewe travelled much of the world, writing 11 books on the subject of his journeys, biographies and cuisine. Crewe was co-proprietor of various restaurants, including the now-defunct Brasserie St. Quentin in [[Knightsbridge]], [[London]].
== Early life ==
Crewe was born Quentin Hugh Dodds in 1926, the second son of Major (James) Hugh Hamilton Dodds, CMG, a career diplomat (amongst other postings, Consul-General at Nice),<ref>http://www.cracroftspeerage.co.uk/online/content/crewe1911.htm</ref><ref>The New Extinct Peerage 1884-1971: Containing Extinct, Abeyant, Dormant and Suspended Peerages With Genealogies and Arms, L. G. Pine, Heraldry Today, 1972, page 90</ref> and Lady Annabel Crewe-Milnes, the daughter of [[Robert Crewe-Milnes, 1st Marquess of Crewe|the Marquess of Crewe]]. His older brother, [[Terence O'Neill]], was a politician who served as the [[Prime Minister of Northern Ireland]] from 1963 to 1969.
During Crewe's early childhood, his father was British Consul in Sicily, before being transferred to the French Riviera when his friendship with [[Haile Selassie]] made it impossible to remain in Italy. With his parents living abroad, the young Quentin spent much of his childhood in the care of various relatives in England. His father was keen that he should be a sportsman, and tried to teach him to shoot, fence or ride, without any success. Crewe would regularly fall over.
Crewe was educated at [[Eton College|Eton]], where he was expelled after copying a fire door key and secretly going to London for a day. He went on to [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] and tried to study law and economics, but he spent so much time partying that he was expelled for indolence. He was falling over so much that he took to walking with a stick, although he did achieve sporting success as a cox.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Obituary: Quentin Crewe|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-quentin-crewe-1185256.html|accessdate = 2015-09-22}}</ref> In 1945 his family changed their name to Crewe after his mother inherited what remained of Lord Crewe's estates.
Despite the doctor's gloomy prediction of a death by 16, Crewe survived his teens, although he did become weaker and his falls more frequent. His condition steadily deteriorated until he was using a wheelchair full-time at age 29.
Crewe was married three times; in 1956, to Martha Sharp, by whom he had a son and a daughter, in 1961, to Angela Huth, by whom he had a son and a daughter, and in 1970, to Sue Cavendish, by whom he had a son and a daughter.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/obituary-quentin-crewe-1185256.html</ref>
== Recognition ==
Crewe appeared as a "castaway" on the [[BBC Radio]] programme ''[[Desert Island Discs]]'' twice, on 21 January 1984,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/features/desert-island-discs/castaway/5890e5c6#p009mhtm|title=Desert Island Discs - Castaway : Quentin Crewe|work=[[BBC Online]]|publisher=BBC|accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref> and on 16 June 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/features/desert-island-discs/castaway/5890e5c6#p0093nfq |title=Desert Island Discs - Castaway : Quentin Crewe|work=[[BBC Online]]|publisher=BBC|accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref>
== Books ==
* ''A Curse of Blossom: A year in Japan'' (1960) * ''The Frontiers of Privilege. A Century of Social Conflict as reflected in The Queen'' (1961) * ''Great Chefs of France: The Masters of Haute Cuisine and their Secrets,'' with Anthony Blake (1978) * ''Quentin Crewe's International Pocket Food Book'' (1980) * ''The Simon and Schuster International Pocket Food Guide'' (1980) * ''In Search of the Sahara'' (1983) * ''The Last Maharaja: A Biography of Sawai Man Singh Li, Maharaja of Jaipur'' (1985) * ''Touch the Happy Isles: Journey Through the Caribbean'' (1987) * ''In the Realms of Gold: Travels through South America'' (1989) * ''Well, I Forget The Rest: The Autobiography of an Optimist'' (1991) * ''Food from France'' (1993) * ''Crewe House: The Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia'' (1995) * ''Letters from India'' (1998)
